Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 52e31629978bbcefc0e14c96272ef77c2dad6a9c
can we make FileBody work with std::format?
I’m not sure what that would entail.  why would that be neccesary when we can just pull the string?
IMO it is a better encapsulation. Since the body knows what it is internally holding, it is better to let the body serialize its internal data.

But that would require serializing the internal data, which might be the file.

I'm open to this at some point, but I'm not sure it would make sense to put the same thing in this patchset, and I'm not sure what it would entail to make this work properly, but would certainly be a ton of code to add the std::formatter template stuff and do the printing.  Considering the existing FileBody doesn't support std::format at the moment, I think we can treat this as something additional added later?
Acknowledged
Is it better to have assignment operator overload with string /stirng_view param in FileBody?
why would overloading operator= be better?  str() is more explicit.

The body is a polymorphic container. It can accept multiple value types. So overloading the assignment operator will be scalable. We need not add new explicit APIs for each type. The assignment operator will do the job. For the incompatible types, it will show an error.

> The body is a polymorphic container. It can accept multiple value types. So overloading the assignment operator will be scalable.

What does "scalable" mean in this context?  I don't believe we have a scaling problem, there are only two types represented for the moment.

> We need not add new explicit APIs for each type. The assignment operator will do the job. For the incompatible types, it will show an error.

The two citations below are from the coding standard that says the opposite.  operator overloading doesn't properly convey what's going on (we're loading a file, or loading a string).


https://isocpp.github.io/CppCoreGuidelines/CppCoreGuidelines#c163-overload-only-for-operations-that-are-roughly-equivalent

In addition:
https://isocpp.github.io/CppCoreGuidelines/CppCoreGuidelines#c164-avoid-implicit-conversion-operators

"Now that we have a custom boost http body class, we can use it in more
cases". After reading this sentence from the commit log, I thought we could add more body types in the future. That is the reason for the scalability comment.

Yes if it is an unrelated operation I agree. But to me assigning a string data and file data to Body is not unrelated. Both are trying to set the data source for the body.

When we add more body types in the future, I would expect that being able to differentiate "set string" from "set file" to be useful.

Would you prefer methods that were explicitly called set, instead of returning the string or file reference?

IMO, operator overloading doesn't fit with the coding standard, as I provided the details above.
Sure I am okay with that
Should we change the name of the body given that it is handling general case now.
that’s a good idea.  I can put that in a separate commit.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69126
why should we return optional here? I don't see any error case here?
Because fileSize is an optional.  fileSize is an optional because the file might not have a size (streaming payload).
but why filesize should be optional?
fileSize is an optional because the file might not have a size (streaming payload).
Changed fileSize to be a value, not optional.

looks like if file open fails body defaults to string body. Is this correct? The intent of the user may be to send file data. If there is an error aren't we supposed to send an error response in this case? If the assumption is that stringbody will have coresponding error string, then it is a readability issue. The error case is not explicit here while just reading this file alone.

the body starts as string (which is empty string). any error response would be in a string body, like it already is today.  why would there be a separate string body for error strings returned to the user?

if the file fails to open, it goes back to a string.  what changes are you looking for here in code?

There is no way to determine what the current body type is. We are depending on the order of condition check to determine it. This will not scale as soon as we add another type. IMO the code lacks locality of reasoning. Just by reading this file, we will never know what the current type is. Variant is good in that respect. An experienced bmcweb developer may know that the string body may hold an error string, but that is not evident in the code.

> There is no way to determine what the current body type is.

Why would that be required to a user outside the class?  only the body writer needs to know what type is currently contained, right?

> We are depending on the order of condition check to determine it. This will not scale as soon as we add another type.

If this is a hypothetical problem, lets defer that discussion until we want to add another type to this class.  Lets keep this discussion about THIS patchset.  I'm happy to have discussions about what happens when we add a third or Nth type to this, but only when we are actually ready to add that type.

> IMO the code lacks locality of reasoning. Just by reading this file, we will never know what the current type is.

Would adding a comment above the str declaration help?

> Variant is good in that respect. An experienced bmcweb developer may know that the string body may hold an error string, but that is not evident in the code.



To be honest, I'm not really sure what code changes you're asking for here.  Are you asking for this to change to ?
```
std::variant<std::string, file_posix>
```

I had a version of this patchset that did that, but the code got fairly complicated with doing all the std::visit stuff for the writer, we had to open the file, then std::move it into place instead of just opening it in place, and there was a condition around what happens when we encounter a variant with a file object that isn't open.  The "is_open" check was actually from the variant version of that patchset.

We've always put a 500 error string in the string body, because it might be mixed with value values in the response to the user (only part of your query might have failed).  I'm happy to discuss doing something different, but that really feels like a separate discussion from this patchset, which is handling errors how we currently handle them, in the string body.

Why would that be required for a user outside the class? only the body writer needs to know what type is currently contained, right?

I was talking about the readability. How the body handles different types and its error cases are not evident. If we use variant it is evident. But as you said it comes with calls-to-visit which may look unreadable.
..... can this be resolved then?  Or is there a code change you're looking for?
Acknowledged

Maybe adding a comment for mandatory checking of ec and setting the appropriate error string as the body will be useful here. Otherwise, users will ignore the case and assume that the file response is successful.
I added a comment about checking the error code.  We can't set an error string in the body here, because in this context, we don't know if this is redfish, dbus rest, or some other protocol.
Acknowledged
shouldn't we report back the size query error?
intentionally not.  the fd might be a pipe, with no actual size.
Acknowledged
since pipe support is removed, shouldn't we report back the error?
we do on line 135
My bad, I missed the return statement. should we do this assignment(ec={})here?It confused me.
Marking done.  Feel free to reopen if you still want to continue the discussion.
why maxSize required?

Because nghttp2 gives fixed size buffers to fill results into.  If body returns > nghttp2 buffer size, we now need complex buffering in nghttp2 that largely doesn't get used, because most of the time the buffers are the same size.

Adding this parameter lets nghttp2 communicate its max buffer size, so the code is simpler.
Acknowledged
read==readReq and EOF can happen right? can't we use remain==0 instead?

> read==readReq and EOF can happen right?

Yes, it can, and in that case, this code loops one more time, and gets a read of zero, and handles the condition correctly.

> can't we use remain==0 instead?

The file might be generated programmatically, and we might not know the size, as is the case in this unit test that uses a pipe:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69063/21/test/http/http_file_body_test.cpp#116
I am not sure how payload size will work in the case of pipe. If payload size is zero then http clients may not parse the body right?
for pipe payloads the payload size is undefined, not zero.  Not providing a content length is allowed in http specs.

But it depends on the client, right? Some clients will avoid parsing the body if the content length is not present. So if we want to mandate clients to look for the body, we should pass a valid length, right? So it looks like a server problem to me

> But it depends on the client, right?
> Some clients will avoid parsing the body if the content length is not present.

Can you provide pointers to these clients?  Ideally the line where they don't parse if the content-length isn't provided on a chunked transfer encoding?  That would be a surprise to me.

> So if we want to mandate clients to look for the body, we should pass a valid length, right? So it looks like a server problem to me

Actually, I've removed all ability to do pipes in this patchset, and files are required to have a size.  While I think in the future it would be useful, we don't have a use case, and when we do, we can add it, along with the relevant tests.

Thank you for keeping my honest.
can we enhance it to handle writing to a file if the body is opened with a file fd?

That's a good idea, and actually why I started this patchset, but would certainly be a different patch to add that functionality.  (if you're interested in adding it, feel free).  We don't have any code that writes a request directly to a file today, and we'd have to handle multi-part to do redfish uploads, which would involve the file body becoming multi-part aware.

it's certainly something we can talk about in the future.
Acknowledged
why only str assignment? shouldn't we do this instead response.body() = res.response.body(); ?

Because the old implementation didn't copy file bodies, due to not having a copy operator for a file handle.  Now that we have one, you're right, it's pretty reasonable to just copy the whole body.

Changed to just copy the body.
can't we change back to string& instead of string*? Now we know str() will always return a valid ref right?
Sure, but lets do that in another patch.
Acknowledged
removing optional return from body.payloadSize() can simplify this code
I've removed optional support.
This is where maxSize is used.

Seems reasonable to me. 
Abhilash has been more involved here so would like to see him +1
will be nicer if we avoid this copy.Maybe by adding a new API in the file body that accepts an out buffer. Can be in another patch set
I think it goes away in the simplify http2 buffering patchset (not sure though)
do we really need this loop for static buffer?
Acknowledged
this also goes away in a later patchset in the series.
flat_map has performance advantage because of contiguous memory right? is it because it is negligible?
in this case it’s done to avoid having to implement a move operator on the values.  the performance difference should be low to unmeasurable in actual code.  most of the time goes to io
and actually, I changed to std::map, to denote that better.  We might change it out for something like std::array later, because we know the number of streams is a fixed size (4).
My +1 is more "seems reasonable, testing seems reasonable, has had reviewers involved from the beginning"
